task: Classify each tweet according to its primary message type.

instructions.goal: Assign one label from {attack, constituency, information, media, mobilization, personal, policy, support, other}.
rules: Return exactly one label or 'ABSTAIN' if the tweet does not clearly fit any class.
Label based on the author's intent, not quoted material.
If multiple classes apply, choose the primary one according to the text’s dominant purpose.

attack.definition: The message attacks another politician or political party.
positive_indicators: Negative adjectives or verbs directed at another politician or party.
Criticism, accusation, or moral condemnation.
Sarcasm or blame directed toward named political figures.
near_misses: Institutional critique without targeting an individual (→ information).
examples: Senator X voted against helping our veterans—unacceptable.
The administration’s incompetence on border security is costing lives.
Once again, Democrats put politics before people.
Senator Y claims to care about families but blocks childcare relief.
My opponent has spent a decade ignoring small businesses.
This is pure hypocrisy from the same party that ballooned the deficit.
The governor’s reckless policies hurt working families.
Unbelievable spin from the White House—Americans deserve the truth.
They lecture about unity while sowing division daily.
Shameful performance today by the House majority.

constituency.definition: Discusses the politician’s constituency, local community, or state-level matters.
positive_indicators: Mentions of local regions, towns, parishes, or state-specific issues.
Announcements of grants, visits, or constituent services.
Expressions of pride in local achievements.
near_misses: National policy affecting all states (→ policy).
Calls to attend events or rallies (→ mobilization).
examples: Proud to secure $5M in infrastructure funding for Baton Rouge bridges.
Honored to meet farmers in Tangipahoa Parish discussing crop insurance.
Congratulations to Lafayette High on winning the robotics championship!
Our coastal restoration project just broke ground—thank you, Louisiana!
Joined local veterans at the Shreveport VA to discuss care improvements.
Celebrating Lake Charles’ new small business incubator opening today.
Our office helped hundreds recover lost FEMA benefits—call us if you need help.
Working with mayors across the parish to rebuild after last year’s storm.
Great turnout at the Baton Rouge town hall—thanks to everyone who came.
Excited to see new jobs coming to Ascension Parish!

information.definition: Provides factual or procedural information about government actions or public events in a neutral tone.
positive_indicators: Objective reporting of votes, hearings, or legislative updates.
Mentions of agencies or departments issuing statements.
Use of numbers, dates, or links to official sources.
near_misses: Advocacy or opinionated policy discussion (→ policy).
Calls to act or donate (→ mobilization).
examples: Today the Senate passed the Infrastructure Investment Act by a 68-32 vote.
FEMA has extended disaster assistance registration through March 1.
The President signed the CHIPS Act into law this afternoon.
My office will be closed Monday for Veterans Day.
The Committee on Energy will hold a hearing tomorrow at 10 AM.
The unemployment rate fell to 3.8% in February.
CDC updated its travel guidelines today—details here: [link]
The Department of Education launched a new FAFSA portal.
My amendment to strengthen rail safety was adopted in committee.
Treasury announced new sanctions against foreign cyber actors.

media.definition: Highlights or promotes the politician’s interaction with media outlets or coverage in press, TV, radio, or podcasts.
positive_indicators: Mentions of interviews, op-eds, or appearances on media programs.
References to journalists or publications.
Use of 'tune in', 'watch', 'read', or similar verbs.
near_misses: Sharing news unrelated to self-appearance (→ information).
examples: I’ll be on @CNN at 8 PM discussing infrastructure funding—tune in!
Read my op-ed in the @NYTimes on bipartisan climate action.
Appreciate @NPR for highlighting our veterans’ housing bill.
Catch my interview with @FoxNews this morning on energy prices.
Proud to join @MeetThePress to talk about healthcare reform.
Just finished a great conversation with @Politico about small business growth.
Watch my appearance on @MSNBC on student loan forgiveness here: [link]
Thank you to local media for covering our flood-relief efforts.
Sharing my perspective on @washingtonpost’s latest analysis of inflation.
Appeared on @CBSNews to discuss the upcoming budget vote.

mobilization.definition: Aims to mobilize supporters to act, attend, volunteer, donate, or vote.
positive_indicators: Direct calls to action (join, vote, volunteer, donate, sign).
Inclusive motivational tone.
Promotion of campaign or advocacy events.
near_misses: General policy discussion without action request (→ policy).
examples: Join me this Saturday in Baton Rouge for our campaign kickoff!
We need your voice—call your senator and demand climate action now.
Early voting starts today! Make your plan to vote.
Sign our petition to protect Social Security from cuts.
Donate $5 to help us reach voters across Louisiana.
We can win this—knock doors, make calls, get involved!
Let’s stand together for reproductive rights.
Retweet to spread the word: polls close at 8 PM.
Volunteer shifts available this weekend—sign up here: [link]
Share your story about how student debt impacts you.

personal.definition: Expresses personal emotions, sympathy, gratitude, or reflections unrelated to policy or campaigns.
positive_indicators: Condolences, congratulations, or emotional reflections.
Holiday greetings or family mentions.
Expressions of empathy or personal gratitude.
near_misses: Congratulating a colleague for political success (→ support).
examples: Heartbroken by the loss of former Senator Smith. My prayers are with his family.
Happy Thanksgiving to everyone celebrating with loved ones today.
Grateful for another year serving the people of Louisiana.
Sending strength to the communities affected by today’s tornadoes.
Proud of my daughter for finishing her first marathon!
Thinking of all who lost loved ones on 9/11—never forgotten.
Thank you to the firefighters who risk their lives daily.
Enjoying a quiet Sunday with family before returning to D.C.
Wishing everyone a safe and happy Independence Day!
My heart goes out to the victims of the school shooting in Nashville.

policy.definition: Advocates or explains political policy positions, legislation, or reforms.
positive_indicators: Discussion of bills, reforms, or proposals.
Substantive argumentation about public policy goals.
Use of verbs like 'reform', 'expand', 'ensure', 'invest'.
near_misses: Personal attack while referencing policy (→ attack).
examples: We need comprehensive immigration reform that secures the border and protects Dreamers.
I’m introducing a bill to expand access to affordable childcare.
Our plan will cut prescription drug costs for seniors.
Climate change is the defining challenge of our generation—action can’t wait.
Broadband is infrastructure; rural communities deserve high-speed internet.
We must defend workers’ right to organize and earn a fair wage.
No family should go bankrupt because of medical bills.
Investing in renewable energy creates jobs and lowers emissions.
Every child deserves a world-class education—let’s fund our schools.
I support criminal-justice reform to end mandatory minimums.

support.definition: Expresses endorsement or praise for another politician, organization, or campaign.
positive_indicators: Endorsement or support statements ('proud to support', 'standing with').
Mentions of cooperation or teamwork with colleagues.
Gratitude toward political allies.
near_misses: Supporting a policy proposal rather than a person (→ policy).
examples: Proud to endorse Jane Doe for Congress—she’ll fight for working families.
Standing with @SenX in the fight for reproductive freedom.
Honored to receive @Union’s endorsement for re-election.
Thank you @POTUS for your leadership on infrastructure.
Excited to campaign alongside @RepY this weekend in Georgia.
Grateful for the support of teachers across our state.
Thrilled to back Governor Z’s re-election campaign.
Congratulations to @SenZ on her confirmation as Secretary of Energy!
I fully support the bipartisan effort led by @SenABC.
Endorsing @CandidateQ—she’s the leader our district needs.

other.definition: Tweets that do not fit any of the above categories; often informal, humorous, or off-topic.
positive_indicators: Non-political content or casual observations.
Humor, memes, or personal remarks without clear political intent.
Meta-social posts or generic engagement thanks.
examples: Coffee count: 3. Monday is winning.
Just boarded another delayed flight—D.C. here I come.
Big day for the team—go Tigers!
Retweeting this just because it made me laugh.
Thank you to everyone who follows—appreciate the support!
Nothing beats a Louisiana sunset.
My staff just told me it’s National Donut Day—time to celebrate.
The Capitol hallways feel emptier this week.
Can’t believe it’s already August.
My phone battery didn’t survive today’s hearing.

fields.label: one of {attack, constituency, information, media, mobilization, personal, policy, support, other, ABSTAIN}
fields.rationale: one-to-two sentence explanation of why the label fits
